text: A young Admiral receives an encoded message from a radiotelegraph and interprets it for a group of Army commanders aboard a warship. An Army division must be diverted to support the Marines on Guadalcanal, an island which none of them is familiar with but which it appears of critical importance in maintaining the supply route between the United States and Australia now in the first of the war. The Army commanders tell him that two divisio are available; each is already at sea. The choice of whic deploy is his and, after a few seconds of hesitation, he makes it. He asks them to return to him some day in the future and to tell him, since he must remain far from the fighting, about their experience in the ordeal to come. Soldiers in the Civil war,.he says, spoke of “seeing the Elephant”: it was as though in combat a strange, awesome creature would appear, whose features one could not quite describe to anyone who had not seen it for himself. He wo like to hear from them what this Elephant is.
FIRST SGT. WELSH sits in the brig of a warship, talking w PFC WITT, a young man from Breathitt County, Kentucky, a regular and formerly a regimental boxer.
I can put you up for a court- martial, or I can give you non- judicial punishment. Your choice, up or down. It's a felony offense to strike an officer -- that includes an NCO.
It ain't right.
We're going to send you to a place where you learn or you don't. They're going to shape you up.
What did the Captain say?
Captain don't want you. Company don't want you.
You fixed it that way.

You were gambling. You got mad because you lost. I've read your record. You been a loser all your life. You don't fool me. You'll never amount to nothing. (after a pause) You hit an NCO from another unit in a war zone. Normally you'd go to Leavenworth.
Baloney!
This isn't a normal situation. I worked a deal. Consider yourself lucky. If this got to Battalion, you'd be court-martialed. Maybe hanged.
Nonsense.

A felony offense, in a war zone. I've had trouble with you since Hawaii. You're a bad soldier. You'd let us down. Welsh leaves. The steel door crashes shut behind him. wit turns to the prisoner in the next cell, a man named HOKE.
(after a silence) What a jerk!
Yeah. Partly he's right, though... I screwed up my life. I thowed away my pearl.

A LEGEND appears over a DISTANT VIEW of a lovely South Pacific island: “Guadalcanal, 9 November 1942.” Two trans ships of the U.S. Navy have sneaked up from the south in first graying flush of dawn to deliver fresh reinforcemen troops.  7. For their crews, this is a routine mission and one they k well; but to the men in the hold, the trip is neither rou nor known.

CORPORAL FIFE, the orderly room clerk, sits against a bulkhead, sick with fear. Beads of moisture cover the ste walls. The fighting men of C-for-Charlie Company pick the wet shirts loose from their armpits, look at their watche and wait impatiently. The bunks are covered with their ge there is nowhere to sit except in the companionways. On Fife's right, PVTS MAZZI and TILLS clutch their knees.
You think we'll catch a fucking air raid?

How the hell do I know? All I know, them crew guys said they din’t catch no air raid last time they made this run. On the other hand, time before last they almost got blew up. What do you want me to tell you?
You're a big help, Tills: nothin’ Tell me nothin’. I'll tell you somethin’. We're sittin’ out here on this ocean like a couple fucking ducks in these here boats, that’s what.
I already know that.

Yeah? Well, brood on it, Tills. Brood on it. In one place a blackjack game has been started. Elsewhere little knots of men have formed and stand or sit talking earnestly to each other with widened eyes while hardly hearing what is said. Every so often an LCI, caught wrong a wave, BANGS against the hull and REVERBERATES through t closed space of the dim hold, an anguished STEEL CRY. On Fife's left, PRIVATE FIRST CLASS DOLL is standing with CORPORAL QUEEN, a huge, amiable Texan.
Well, we'll soon know what it feels like.
What what feels like?
To be shot at.
Hell, I've been shot at. Hell ain't you, Queen?
I only just hope there aren't any planes today. That's all.
Well, I reckon if I'm goin’a get me that pistol, I better get with it Those fucks in the next compartment ought be about nervous enough by now. Anybody want to come along?
You'll do better on your own. Doll stops in front of Mazzi and Tills. He nods at the crowded portholes.
Ain't you watchin’ the fun?
Ain't interested.
I guess it is pretty crowded.
Wouldn't be interested if it wadn't.
I'm on my way to get me that pistol.
Yeah? Well, have fun.
Yeah; have fun.
You guys'll wish you had one, once we get ashore, and run into some of them Samurai sabers.
All I want is to get ashore. And off of this fat sitting fucking duck we all sittin' on out here on this flat water.
Hey, Doll, you get around. You think we're liable to catch an air raid?
How the fucking hell would I know? We might, we might not.
Thanks.
Prob'ly they'll wait to hit us at the beach.
(ignoring Tills) If we do, we do. What's the matter? You scared, Mazzi?
Scared? ‘Course I ain't scared! Are you?
No.
Okay then. Shut up. Doll throws back his head and laughs and steps out throug the bulkhead.
That guy just ain't hep. He’s as unhep as a box.
You think he'll get a pistol?  10.
Hell no, he won't get no pistol.
Right now, I couldn't care less. All I want is to get off this fucking boat here.

Well, you ain't by yourself, Tills. All I know, I never bargained for nothin’ like this when I signed up in this man's Army back in the Bronx before the war. How did I know they was gonna be a fucking war, hanh? Answer me that.
You tell me. You're the hep character around here, Mazzi.

All I know, old Charlie Company always gets screwed. Always. And I can tell you whose fault it is. Bugger Stein's, that's who. First he gets us stuck off on this boat clean away from our own outfit where we don't know a fucking soul. Then he gets us stuck way down in fourth pace on the list to get off this son of a bitch. At the other end of the companionway, CAPT. JAMES STEIN t privately with First Sergeant Welsh.
I think our outfit looks pretty capable, pretty solid, don't you Sergeant? Welsh grins at him insolently. There is a look of dark foreboding that never leaves his face, even when he grins

Yeah -- for a bunch of slobs about to get their ass shot off. Stein does not answer him. Welsh is mad. He is insane, Tr a madman, and Stein never has understood him. He has no respect for anything or anybody . But it doesn't really matter. Stein can afford to overlook his impertinences because he is so good at his job.  11.
Hello, Doll. How's it going? Everything okay? Feeling a little nervous?
(warily) No, sir. Stein nods, dismissing him. Doll salutes and goes on out through the watertight door, wondering what Stein meant.

Furious, Doll makes his way through the forward hold. He not know how much time he still has. Then, suddenly, he s a .45 hanging from the end of a bed frame. Three bunks aw group of men clusters around a nervous crap game. He has make his move now, time is running out. He lifts the pist off the bunk frame and buckles it around his waist.
Hey, you! Hey, soldier! Doll turns around to see two men, one a PRIVATE and one a SERGEANT, coming toward him. Will they turn him in?
That's my pistol you're wearin’, soldier.
He saw you take it off the bunk. So don't try to lie out of it, soldier. Doll forces a slow, cynical grin to spread across his fac Slowly he undoes the belt and passes it over.

How long you been in the Army, mack? You ought know better than to leave your gear layin' around like that. You might lose it someday. Both men stare back at him, their eyes widening slightly the new idea, new attitude, replaces their own of righteo indignation.
Well, you better not have such sticky fingers, soldier.  12.
Anything layin' around out in the open that loose, is fair game to me. And to any other soldier. Tell your boy he oughtn't to tempt people so much.
Hear that, Drake? You better take better care of your gear.
Yeah. He sure better. Or he won't have it long.

Outside, in the hatchway area, Doll stops and laughs. It all one big lie! Entering the bunk area on the deck above everything works perfectly for him. On a field pack at th edge of the companionway he sees not one but two pistols. There is not a man in this entire end of the bunk area. T is all there is to it. All Doll has to do is step over, p up one of the pistols and put it on.
Doll returns to C-for-Charlie in the second forward hold. Tills, Mazzi and Fife have not moved. Doll steps up with hands on his hips, his right one resting on the pistol.
Hello, lover-boy. Where you been?
Around... Well, what do you think?
Think of what?
Nothin'. The war. He turns on his heel and goes on inside among the bunks.
Well, what do you say now, hep guy?
Just what I fucking said before. The guy's a jerkoff.  13.
He's got a pistol.
So he's a jerkoff with a pistol.
While you're a hep guy, without a pistol.
That's right. What's a fucking pistol? Leave it, Tills; leave it You wanna do somethin', go do somethin'.
I think I will. MESS SERGEANT STORM has gathered his cooks for a bull session.
(grinning crazily) What are you doing with that fucking pistol, Doll?
What pistol?
This pistol. Welsh grabs the pistol on Doll's hip and, with it, pulls slowly forward and slowly, the grin fades from Welsh's fa
Well, I...

And what if somebody comes around here to Capt. Stein and wants to search this outfit for a stolen pistol? 'Ey? Have you ever thought of that? And what if I then knowin' who had it, was forced to tell Bugger Stein where it was? Huh? Have you thought of that, too?
Would you do that, Top?  14.
You bet your sweet ass I would! Welsh bellows it with startling suddenness right into his face. The CRASH of the landing craft against the hull continues, relentless and unnerving.
Well -- Do you think anybody’11 come around?
No! I don't! Then, as slowly as it disappeared, the sly, ominous grin comes back over the sergeant's face. He lets Doll go and, in the same motion, flings the holstered pistol away from him.

Clean it. It's prob'ly dirty. Any man'd leave it layin' around's a fuckass soldier anyway. Wherever his glance falls, the nearby men beneath it stir uneasily and drop their eyes and fall to doing something: adjusting a strap, checking a tie-rope, rubbing a riflest
Fife sits to Bell's right, sunk in melancholy. BELL is a strong, quiet-voiced private.
(after a pause) I read in your 201 file you were an officer before the war.
You told anybody else?
No. How'd you end up a private?
Because of my wife. I was in the Corps of Engineers, we'd never been separated before, not even for a night. I took it for four months and then I quit. Resigned.  15.
Yeah?

They sent me back to the States. They told me I'd never get another commission, they said they'd see to it that I got drafted, and that I'd for damn sure be in the Infantry. We had eight months together.
Why, the sons of bitches! Where is she now?
Home. With her folks. How old are you, Fife?
Twenty-two.
Well, I'm thirty.
Why don't you want any of the guys to know?
Enlisted men don't like officers... The only reason I've told you is so you'll know why I don't want it mentioned.
(appearing suddenly) All right, fuckface! Where's that platoon roster I told you to fix up for me?
(indignantly) I already did it! I made it up and turned it in to you, Welsh.
You what! You did no such fucking thing, Fife. I don't have it, do I?  16.
He signals Fife to follow him around a corner into the latrine. There he backs Fife up against the wall.

You think you're a big grown-up man, but you're gust a punk kid -- a coward. There’s nowhere you can run now. You're in a box. A moving box. You've never learned that your life, and you -- they don't mean a goddamned thing to the world, and they never will.
Suddenly the KLAXON HORN goes off, RESOUNDING through the CLANGING, overheated hold and deafening everybody -- an immense sound that causes everyone to jump, even Welsh.
Get your gear and shape up!
All right! Off and on! Drop your cocks and grab your socks! Everybody struggles into their equipment. Bulging in all directions, they find the stairs difficult to navigate.
Geez, my ass is draggin’. All this gear.
Mor’n your ass‘ll be draggin’ soon.

They emerge at last into the sunshine and fresh sea air o deck. Looking up to the bridge, Capt. Stein sees LT. COL. GORDON TALL, the Battalion Commander. They exchange salut By squads and by platoon, the men go over the side and clamber down the four-story-high side of the ship on the and into the chain of LCIs that shuttle back and forth fr the shore.  17.
The ASST. PILOT salutes them in best naval officer style.
Well, look what we got here. Your outfit's lucky. Old Nippy'1ll be comin' along in about fifteen minutes.
How do you know?

Just got news from the airstrip. Transports must've been spotted. You're getting off just ahead of time. You're lucky. Fife grabs the gunnel to keep his balance in the jouncing swaying craft, and looks back at the dwindling ship.
But won't the fighter planes --

They always get some of them. But some always get through. Jerk the lead! Ahead, Doll sees the shore and sand beach and coco palms gradually coming closer. Beyond them lies the dark green of jungle, with the mass and power of the mountains risin behind it to rocky peaks.
Grab holt and prepare to land! Everybody out! No transfer slips!

Suddenly, they are stumbling through the water. The ramp already rising, as the craft goes into reverse and pulls out to go for another load. Fife expects some protest, so visible sign of enemy resistance, but not a shot is fired They dart across the beach to the line of coco palms, thrashing dryly in the mid-morning breeze. There they res waiting for orders from Battalion. Didn't the Army know t were no Japanese here?  18. If they failed to realize this, what else don't they know Two SCOUTS come scampering out of the grove up ahead and report to Capt. Stein.

We went in about a mile, sir. Didn't find nothing. Some empty oil drums. A burned spot. Hadn't nobody been around there for at least a week. Stein nods, puzzled. Suddenly a CRY goes up. One SOLDIER flings up an arm and yells, "There they are!" The CRY is taken up all up and down the beach. High up in the sun-bright sky, a number of little specks serenely along toward the channel where the two ships lie Presently, a gentle SIGHING becomes audible. Then a GEYSE water, followed by another, then another, pops high up ou the sea, until at last a stick of three bombs falls almos directly alongside an LCI that is just putting off. When spout of water subsides, they see there is nothing left o the LCI, only a few figures bobbing in the water who, und the weight of their full packs, rapidly become fewer.

The survivors of the destroyed LCI are landed by a rescue boat not far from C-for-Charlie Company, and gently led o carried up from the beach to a nearby field dressing stat Some of them are still vomiting seawater from their ordea for-Charlie drifts up toward the dressing station, consum with a morbid curiosity. DALE, the muscular, intense seco cook, with perpetually snapping eyes, makes the only comm

They should of let them have it with the antiaircraft from the ships! They could of got a lot more of them. If I'd been there, and had my hands on one of them forty millimeters, I'd of let them have it, orders or no orders. That's what I'd of done.
You'd shit, too.

They trudge through the mangroves to their bivouac, led b the Route Guide from regimental headquarters.  19. The roads are seas of soft mud, axle-deep on the trucks. is impossible to march on or in them. The only way for th men to move ahead at all is to travel in two lines, one o either side, picking their way over the great rolls of dr mud, turned back as though by a plow. Staggering, and senseless with exhaustion, they march on. By the time the reach their bivouac, it has begun to rain.

C-for-Charlie works doggedly to set up camp. The rain com straight down, unbreathed-upon by any wind, in huge, fat drops so close together that it seems a solid sheet of wa Turning around, Fife sees that some of the men (Marl amon them) are playing in the mud, sitting down and sliding ar like children in snow, clowning and laughing.
Welsh enters the orderly room tent and nods at Capt. Stei
Sir, the company's allotment of eight-man personnel tents hasn't arrived from the ship.
Have the men break packs and put' up their shelter tents. (as Welsh grins) Goddamn it, Sergeant, I know it's a ridiculous order, too! Now go and tell them! That's an order!
Yes, sir!
Welsh has given the men Stein's order, with sardonic reli and they are setting about it.
He's nuts! Plain fucking nuts! Tills sits on a five-gallon water can buttoning their she halves together. Mazzi gathers their combined ten tent pe having stretched the wet ropes as best he can.  20.

You think these goddamn little old pegs going to hold in this muck? I was company commander of this company, there'd be a lotta changes around here, and pretty damn fuckin' quick. And up yours, Tills. You about finished there?
Look, Mazzi, I want to ask you somethin'. You think there's any germs in this mud?
Germs? Sure there's germs.
You really think so?
Why, hell yes. Don't you read the papers? This island's loaded with all kinds of germs. And where do you find germs? In dirt. Malaria germs...
(interrupting) Malaria germs are in the mosquitoes.
Sure, but where do they get them? From dirt. There's --
No. They get them from other people who got malaria.
Okay, sure. But where they come from first? Everybody knows germs come from dirt and bein' dirty. You'll prob'ly be sick as a dog tomorra, Tills.
You're a son of a bitch, Mazzi.
Who? Me? What'd I do? You ast me a question, I answered it for you. (MORE )

You din’t %#éeZie atown' hd slidin’ around in that mud, did you? Sure, I laughed, I cheered them on. That didn't cost me nothin’. Trouble with you, Tills, you’re a jerkoff. You're awys gettin’ sucked into somethin’. Take a lesson, kid. You don't see me gettin’ sucked into nothing. Around them, other men are working and other shelter tent are going up in long, even lines. The ground is a soggy m Doll, the proud pistol thief, swaggers over to his pal Fi who has just finished putting up the tent which he shares with his assistant, PFC BEAD. Bead is a draftee, a health eighteen-year-old from Iowa, the youngest man in the outf
We still got a couple of hours before sundown. Bunch of us is goin’ to look at the jungle. wanta come?
I don't know if I ought to. The sergeant might need me around here for something.
I'll go, Doll! I'll go!
You ain't invited.
Whada you mean I ain't invited? Anybody can go that wants to, can't they? Doll leaves. Bead is crestfallen.
Never mind him.

A dozen of the men from C-for-Charlie -- among them Big Queen, the huge Texan, and Private Bell, the former offic approach the high wall of jungle curiously and gingerly. Parrots screech from nowhere, startling them. Huge vines creepers hang from the canopy in great festooning arcs.  22. Giant tree trunks tower straight up , far above their hea their thin blade-like roots often higher than a man's hea Other POVs: a skull shrine, a wood carving of a man the features of whose face have been eroded by the weather, a python, strange tropical fruits, some split open by raidi ants. Suddenly Queen discovers a bloodstained shirt. For a mome he thinks of saying nothing. He could pass it by and none the rest of them would know. But, noticing his strange hesitation, the MAN next to him sees it too and raises a shout. The other men, who instinctively have spaced themselves out at five-yard intervals as if in a skirmish line, cluster around and peer excitedly.

(Gordon's esp.) Is it American? Fuck yes, it's American. The Japs don't wear khaki like that. That's chino! That's not even Marine khaki! That's Army chino! Well, the Americal Division's here. Maybe he's one of them.
Whoever he was, he was hit pretty bad.
Where'd it hit him?
It keyholed out the back. PRIVATE GORDON, one of the men nearest it, leans down silently and picks it up with a thumb and forefinger, as afraid he might catch a terrible disease from it.
Leave it where you found it. Without a word, Gordon, who still holds it by thumb and forefinger as if it might contaminate him, turns and swin it and lets it go.
Yeah, leave'm lay. The chow WHISTLE sounds clear and shrill through the tree It is an intensely familiar, curiously heart-wringing sou  23.

Tonight C-for-Charlie receives its first dosage of Atabri Standing by the Lister bag at the head of the chow line Storm doles out the yellow pills himself, chaffing everyo good-naturedly, but determined that nobody is going to av taking his medicine.
What the fuck do you bother so hard for?
Because, they going to need all the help they can git.
They going to need a lot more than that.
I know it. The last man in the line has stopped and is looking back them, listening; one of the draftees.
On your way, bud.
(shaking his pills) Some of them so dumb they actu'ly wouldn't take them. If I didn't make them.
So what? They don't take them, maybe they'll get malaria so bad they'll get themself shipped out and save their useless life.
They ain't learned that yet. They will.

We'll be ahead of them. Won't we? We'll make them fucking take them. Won't we? You and me. We know the secret, don't we? We already know about not taking them. Gimme one.  24. Storm holds out the box. Without taking his eyes from Sto face, Welsh reaches down, gets a pill and, thumbing the surface dust off it, pops it into his mouth. Not to be outdone, Storm gets one himself and swallows it as Welsh dry.
You know what it is, don't you? You realize what's happening... There ain't any choice. It ain't going to get any better, either. This war's just the start. You understand that.
Yeah.
Then remember it, Storm; remember it. Bell and Fife sit by themselves eating in silence.

This war is tougher on her than it is on me. Back home there's lights and nightclubs, booze. More to tempt you. I haven't touched another woman since I was called up. Or talked to one. I don't want to feel the desire.
hairs on the table! Closing time!

We believe in each other. You need someone you can believe in. Dale complains to a willing listener about Storm's mistreatment of him. Not far away, Bead is blowing soap bubbles, dipping a ring in the shaving lather he has whip up in the bottom of his helmet.
The night is filled with the stitch of tropical insects. men crouch over the weapons in total and unspeakable insularity.  25.
I always thought I'd be as brave as the next guy, maybe even braver But I m not. You told me about your wife. I'm telling you something.
Everybody's scared.

Not Doll, not Big Un. I got to work harder at it than they do. The only reason I'm here is because I was ashamed for people to think I was a coward. I had to find out if I was yellow or not... I never had a wife and kids. I never been to New York. I don't want to die.
Nobody does.
I hope I can get back -- the way I was -- like I came. They look up at a scuttling noise in the undergrowth, at length discover a coconut crab. (End on CU of crab.)

Stein is writing a letter by candlelight when he hears th noise of a Japanese plane high overhead. (Washing Machine Charlie.) Suddenly the earth is SHAKING around him. Panic an objectless fright seize him, and he surges blindly out his tent, scrambling toward a nearby slit trench. Down the long aisle of the coconut groves, the KLAXONS be their mournful, insistent belching. Above, three weak searchlight beams feebly finger the sky. Now and then the see the single QUICK BLINK of an antiaircraft shell exploding. Finally, there is the SHUTTERING, THIN sound o the motor, or motors, up there in the dark. Then, from th direction of the airfield, come the CA-RUMPING explosions walking slowly toward them in great giant strides. The klaxons keep up their long, monotonous, insane, GROWLING protest, and the antiaircraft guns PUMP their useless laughable shells up into the night sky, as the ball-shrin ROAR of the bombs advances.  26. Suddenly, there is a huge, ear-filling, impersonal, rushi FLUTTER descending like an express train, then a flash of light. It is strange that only one man is wounded. By all rights, there should be many more. The wounded man is Pfc Marl, the Nebraska dry-dirt farmer. A piece of the daisycutter has whistled into his hole and cut off his ri hand as neatly as a surgeon could have done with a knife. When Marl yells, Welsh leaps in with him and puts a tourniquet on him until the medic can get there.

What'm I gonna do now, huh? How'm I gonna work, huh! How'm I donna plow, huh? I mean it. What’m I gonna do now, huh? Take it away! Get that damned thing out of here! I don't want to look at it, goddamn it! It's my hand! The hand is taken away by one of the company MEDICS, who supposed to be trained at this kind of work but actually not as yet, and who stops to vomit behind a tree.
They make artificial ones. They'll make you one like new.
Goddamn it, it's easy for you! How'm I gonna work? I'm a farmer.
Can you walk?

Sure I can walk, goddamn it. Fuck yes, I can walk. But how'm I gonna work? That's the point. Fife watches, trembling within, as Marl is led off into t darkness to the battalion medical station, the first actu wounded casualty in the company.

head_text.subj: WITT AND HOKE AMONG THE MELANESIANS

text: Witt and Hoke have gone AWOL and are living among the Melanesians, unconscious of the passage of the days, of g and evil. The native people live content with what the ea and sea provide them, in peace and harmony. Witt gets to two of them in particular, an older man and a young woman marvels at this society where no one is alone or lives to himself, where all is based on family and clan.  27. He reveals to Hoke a secret from his past and, under the influence of this revelation, decides to return to C-for- Charlie. Hoke tries to discourage him from setting out bu at length, joins him instead.

The men of C-for-Charlie come out into the warm, revivify safety of the sun and look into each other's stubbled, di caked faces to find they are changed men. Faces glower an eyes burn. Suddenly, Fife hears himself hailed by a man standing some distance off, near the supply tent and lean against a coco palm.

Well, Witt! By God! How are you! A troublemaker with a touchy sense of honor, Witt has bee busted several times and twice sent to the stockade on a summary court-martial. This makes him something of a roma hero to Fife, who considers him the only friend besides B that he has in the whole regiment. He rushes over to shak hands, overjoyed to see him. Witt is just as glad, in his way. All his friends are in C-for-Charlie, and he likes t reputation he enjoys here. As Witt sees it, everybody kno he loves C-for-Charlie and for Welsh to ship him out, whi knowing this, only proves his total contempt for Welsh correct.

How'd you find us? You AWOL? I been asking around about you every day, trying to find out were you were. I thought you were in the brig. How long you been hanging around here? Why didn't you come in the orderly tent and get me? Witt's face hardens, almost as though someone had modeled features in quick-setting cement and Fife were watching i dry.
I ain't goin' no place where that poorly son of a bitch of a first sergeant is.
Welsh? Yes, well. Well, you know, I think maybe he's changed some Witt. Since we got here.  28.
He ain't never going to change. Not in no way.
Well, I tell you. It just won't be the same old company, Witt. Going up there without you. I guess that's why I said that.

(warming up) Fife, I can tell you. When I think of old C-for-Charlie goin’ up there into them Japs without me, it like to breaks my heart. I been in this comp’ny -- what now? -- four years. You know how I feel about it. It’s my comp’ny. It ain’t right, that’s all. It ain’t. I belong with the company, Fife, old buddy. (suddenly morose) I don’t know what I can do about it. In fact, there ain’t a damn thing.

Well, I think if you went around to Capt. Stein and told him how you feel, he'd arrange a transfer back for you. Bugger knows how good a soldier you are. Never was a question of that. Right now he's feeling pretty warm and sentimental about the company, leading them into combat and all.
I cain't do that.
Why not?
Because I cain't. You know it.
I honestly think he'll take you back.
Take me back! Take me back! They never should of made me go! (MORE)

It's their Wialiitconitt' djin't mine! I didn't need no discipline. Discipline is what you give a dog! I cain't do that. I won't go and beg them. I appreciate you tryin' to help. (as Fife nods) I mean it.
I know you do. Fife goes on carefully, afraid of making him mad.
Just how bad do you want to get back into the comp’ny?
You know how bad.
Well, the only way you're going to do it is to go to Stein and ask him.
I cain't do that. I tell you it ain't fair. It ain't fair, and it ain't square. Any way you look at it. It ain't justice. It's a traversty of justice.
It's "travesty."
What?
I said you pronounce it tra-ves-ty. Witt stares at him as if he had never seen him before. Th storm cloud, with its flickers of impending electrical discharges, comes back on his face.
Take off! I said take off! Leave! Get out!
I got as much right here as you have.  30.
Fife, I never hit a friend before in my life. Not without givin' them fair warnin' they ain't friends no more. I don't want to start now, either. But I will.
What the hell kind of talk is that? What did I do?
