Bell has never know such eviscerating, ball-shrinking terror.
Hey, Keck! Hey, Keck! We got to get out of here.
I know it.
Can you see them? Can you see where any of them are?
No.
What'll we do?
We know you there, Yank. Yank, we know you there.
Tojo eats shit! He is answered by an angry burst of machine gun FIRE.
Roozover’ eat shit!
You goddamn right he does! When the firing stops, Bell calls softly again.
What’11 we do, Keck?  52.

Listen. All you guys listen. Pass it along so everybody knows. When I holler go, everybody up. Load and lock; have a nuther clip in yore hand. 1st Squad stay put, kneeling position,. fire covering fire. 2nd and 3rd Squads hightail it back over that fold. 1st Squad fire two clips, then scoot. 2nd and 3rd fire covering fire from that fold. If you can’t see nothin’, fire searching fire. Space yore shots. Them positions is about halfway up them ridges. Everybody got it? Then

The slope comes to life. Bell leaps up running, his legs already pistoning before the leap comes down to earth. Sa beyond the little fold of ground, which by now has taken characteristics of huge size, he whirls and begins to FIR cover. When 2nd and 3rd Squads come diving and tumbling b over the tiny crest, Bell is content to throw himself pro press his cheek to the earth, shut his eyes and lie there

God, oh, God! why am I here! Apparently, Keck's plan has worked very well. 2nd and 3rd Squads, having the surprise, have gotten back untouched; 1st Squad has had only two men hit. Bell is looking right one of them as, running hard with his head down, the man boy, named KLINE) jerks his head up suddenly, his eyes wi with start and fright, and cries out "Oh!", his mouth a r pursed hole in his face, and goes down. Anguished cries o "Medic! Medic!" are beginning to be raised now here and t across the field. Back at the CP behind the first swell, Stein watches. See that their Captain can safely stand up on his knees witho being pumped full of holes or mangled, others are now doi it. He is setting them a pretty good example, Stein think still a little astonished by his own bravery. He calls hi two company AIDMEN over.
You two fellows better get on up there. I expect they need you.
Yes, sir.  53.
Go by rushes, if you think you have to. (as they disappear ) I need a runner! A volunteer! Not a single figure moves to come forward or answers him. Stein stares back at them, disbelieving.
I -- can't see what happened up there. I need someone to go up there and find out what's happened. Charlie Dale, the second cook, appears at his elbow, scow with intensity, his face dark and excited.

I'll go, sir. Stein watches him go trotting off bent over at the waist then looks back at the rest of them, somewhat restored. T are now twelve men standing on their knees in a group aro Stein, trying to see what is going on up front. Fife is n however, one of these. Fife is absolutely flattened out a can get, staring at flies stirring in the grass. His rage broken off short by the buzzing WHISTLE of the soundpower phone that Stein has given him care of.
Yes?
What do you mean, "yes"?
I mean this is Charlie Cat Seven. Over.
That's better. This is Seven Cat Ace. Colonel Tall here. I want Captain Stein. Over.

Yes, sir. He’s right here. (to Stein) Colonel Tall wants you. Stein lies down and takes the phone. Despite the din, bot and Fife beside him can hear the colonel clearly. Stein h been caught off guard;  54. he did not expect to be called upon to offer explanations soon. What he hears astounds him to speechlessness.

Magnificent, Stein, magnificent! The finest thing these old eyes have seen in a long time. Beautifully conceived, beautifully executed. You'll be mentioned in Battalion Orders, Stein. Your men came through for you. Over.
Yes, sir. Over.

Best sacrificial commitment to develop a hidden position I have ever seen outside maneuvers. Young Whyte led beautifully. I'm mentioning him, too. I saw him go down in that first melee. Was he hurt bad? But sending in your 2nd too was brilliant. They might very well have carried the ridge, with luck. I don't think they were hurt too bad. Blane led well too. How many of the emplacements did they locate? Did they knock out any? We ought to have those ridges cleaned out by noon. Hello? Hello, Stein? Over?
Yes, sir. Here, sir. Over.
Thought you'd been hit. I said, how many of the emplacements did they locate? Did they knock any of them out? Over.
I don't know. Over.

What do you mean you don't know? How can you not know? Over Stein finds himself in a quandary. He cannot admit what b he and Fife know, which is that he knows nothing about Whyte's attack, did not order it, and until now has belie it bad.  55.
I'm back here. Behind the first swell. Do you want me to stand up? And wave? Over.

No. I can see where you are. I want you to do something. I want you to getup there and see what the situation is, Stein. I want Hill 210 in my hands tonight. To do that I have to have those two ridges by noon. The Admiral got up at dawn for this. Come to life down there, Stein. Out.

(to Welsh) Let's move up. While Stein's Company HQ is trooping forward to the secon the swells, the 1st Platoon continues to lie flat. After first crash and volley and thunder of mortars they all expected to be dead in five minutes. Now, it seems unbelievable but the Japanese do not seem to be able to s them very well. The two company aidmen have moved courageously up amongst Platoon and begun little sorties out after the wounded. I all there are fifteen wounded men, and six dead. The aidm do not bother with the dead, but slowly they retrieve for stretcher-bearers all of the wounded. Bell watches them, astonished. With insouciance, the two them move up and down the slope of the last swell, bandag and salting, dragging and half-carrying. MORTAR SHELLS kn them down, MG FIRE kicks up dirt around them, but nothing touches them. They clump untouchably on, helping the sobb near-helpless men.

location: HILLSIDE, (WITT AND HOKE AMONG THE WOUNDED)
WITT AND HOKE AMONG THE WOUNDED

text: Witt works as a stretcher-bearer. He receives the wounded from the aidmen and does what he can to comfort them. The bleed. They cry. They beg for water. He puts his canteen their lips; he listens; he smooths their hair. He feels strangely close to them. The other men look on the wounded with fear and a hushed They keep their distance, though they cannot help but be curious; fresh blood is so very red. It is all obscene somehow .  56. Something which they feel should not be looked at, but wh they are compelled to look at, with guilty darting glance

location: GRASS AT THE FOOT OF THE RIDGE

text: It is Doll who sees the first Japanese. Sensing the movem around him as men begin to stir and call softly to each other, he raises his head until his eyes show above the slight depression into which he has sprawled. He sees thr figures carrying what could only be a machine gun still attached to its tripod start across the slope back toward Hill 210. Doll slides his rifle up, raises the sight four clicks an lying with only his left arm and shoulder outside his lit hole, sights on the man in front, leading him a little, a squeezes off a SHOT. The rifle bucks his shoulder and the goes down. The two men behind jump sideways together, lik pair of skittish, delicately coordinated horses, and run

I got him! I got him! Doll has killed his first Japanese. For that matter, his first human being of any kind. He feels an impulse to gri silly grin and to laugh. All at once a mortar shell SIGHS down and ten yards away EXPLODES in a fountain of terror and dirt, and Doll disco his confidence hasn't been helped so much after all. Afte moment, he again puts his head up a little. This time he four Japanese preparing to leave the grassy ridge and hea toward the top of Hill 210. They come into si Doll from somewhere on the ridge already running. Doll pulls his ri up into position and fires off FOUR SHOTS. He misses each time. The Japanese disappear into the rocks.
Hey, Queen! You there? You see them Japs leavin’ that left ridge?
I ain’t been seein’ much of nothin’.
Well, why don't you get your fuckin’ head up and look around?
Go fuck yourself, Doll.  57.
No, I'm serious. I counted seven Japs leavin’ that left-hand grassy ridge. I got me one of ‘em.
So?
I think they're pullin’ out of there. Maybe somebody ought to tell the Captain.
You want to be the one?
Why not? Sure. I'll carry the message back to Bugger for you.

You'll do no such goddamn fucking thing. You'll stay right the fuck where you are and shut up. That's an order. Doll does not answer for a moment. Slowly his heart retur to normal. He offered and he was refused.

They'll get us out of this ina little bit. Somebody will. You stay put. I'm ordering you. But the thing that is driving Doll, eating on him, doesn' recede. He has a strange tingling all through his belly a crotch. Off to his right there is a sudden burst of MG FI his ear now knows as Japanese, and immediately after it a of pain.
Sounds like Stearns.

Not my legs! Not my legs! Aidman! Aidman! I'll be all right! Just show me where to go! The tingling in Doll gets stronger and his heart begins t pound again. He has never in his life been excited quite this. Somebody has to get that news to Bugger. Somebody h to be a -- hero. And at once he goes,, up in a flash and running, bent over, his rifle in both hands.  58. A BULLET kicks up dirt two feet to his left and he zigs right. Ten yards further on he zags left. Then, twenty ya further, he nearly collides with Dale, who is just coming to get their news.
Where you going, fuckface?
I'm s’pose to find out what's going on with you people.

They sendin’ out cooks? They must be in bad shape back there. He hurries on past Dale without even looking back. Dale's ears burn with the unprovoked insult. A feral pig flushes from its hiding place in the bushes nearby. Dale SHCJTS a but misses. Behind the second little swell Doll runs almost head-on i Capt. Stein. He comes trotting up, bent over, giggling an laughing, so out of breath he cannot talk. Welsh eyes him contemptuously.
What are you laughing at?
I think they're pullin’ completely out of there, sir.
Who sent you back here?
Nobody , sir. I came myself. I thought it was something you'd want to know.
You're right. It is. I won't forget it, Doll. Doll does not answer, but grins and turns to Fife.
That was exciting. More than all the hunting, gambling and fucking I ever done. All rolled up together.  59.
God damn it, get down! George, get a man with glasses and have him spot the back of that ridge. I want to know the second anybody leaves it. Take mine.

I'll do it myself. Stein gives his binoculars to ist Lt. Band, his exec, the turns back to Doll and begins to question him about the attack, casualties, the present position of the platoon. While they are talking Welsh looks over the crest at the Platoon flattened out and looking back this way, watching their commander, who conceivably might order them to go o the crest again.
You're not really pinned down then. I was told --
Well, we are, in a way, sir. But like you see, I got back all right. We couldn't all come back at once. But two or three at a time could make it, I think. With 2nd Platoon firing covering fire.
We don't even know where those goddamned fucking emplacements are.
They could fire searching fire, couldn't they? Stein glares at him. So does Welsh. Welsh wants to boot t new hero in the ass: already giving the company commander advice!
Cap’n? You want me to go out there and get them men back here for you?
No. No, I can't spare you. Might need you. Anyway, I think I'll leave them there a while. (MORE)
They don't Sdéaim (tanrbie' @Ptting hurt too bad and if we can get up onto that right ridge frontally maybe they can flank it.
Hey, Jim! Hey, Captain Stein! I just saw five more leaving the left ridge, with two MGs. I think they really are pulling out.
Really? Really? Now he hears a voice behind him and looks around to see D staring at him with his narrow close-set eyes snapping bright.
Captain, are there any more jobs you got for me to do?

Yes, Dale. You -- Stein is interrupted by the EXPLOSION of a mortar shell amongst the 2nd Platoon on the swell just ahead of them. thronging bang is almost simultaneous with a loud SCREAM pure fear. A man has thrown himself out of the line back the slope and is bucking and kicking and rolling with bot hands pressed behind him in the small of his back.

I don't think they can see us any better than we can see them. The screaming takes on a new tone, one of realization, ra than the start and surprise and pure fear of before. One the aidmen rushes out to Jacques and, with the help of tw men from 2nd Platoon, tears open his shirt and gets a syr of morphine into him. In a few seconds he quiets. The aid shrugs with despair. Stein is white-faced, his lips tight This is the first of his men he has actually seen wounded
Stretcher-bearers! I believe that's Private Jacques.
But, Jim. Really, Jim, I don't -- There's other men wounded.  61.
God damn you, George, shut up! Leave me alone! The stretcher-bearers arrive out of breath. Stein points the crest to where the aidman still kneels by the casualt
Go get that man. Hoke, the lead stretcher-bearer, plainly thought someone the CP group here was wounded. Now he sees his mistake.
We already got eight or nine down there now that we're not supposed to -- We're not --
God damn it, don't argue withe me! I'm Captain Stein! Go get that man I said! Hoke recoils, upset. Of course nobody is wearing insignia
But, Jim, really, he's not --

God damn you, all of you! Am I in command around here or not! Am I company commander of this outfit or am I not! Am I a captain or a goddamned private! Do I give the orders here or don't I! That man may die. He's hit bad. Get him back to Battalion Aid Station. See if they can't do something to save him.
Yes, sir. We got others that’re hit bad, sir. That was all I meant. we got three down there might die any minute.
That's it, Jim. Don't you see? Don't you think he ought to wait his turn? Isn't that only fair?
Wait his turn? Wait his turn? Fair?  62.
Why put him ahead of some other guy?
Go and get him, like I told you. Back to Battalion Aid Station. I gave you an order, Private.
Yes, sir. Come on, you guys. We're goin’ after that guy.
Well what the hell’re we waitin’ for? Come on, Hoke. Or are you afraid of gettin’ that close to the shooting?
You shut up, Witt. Let me alone. The man he has addressed stands up suddenly. With a rapac grin he marches up to where Welsh half-reclines.

Hello, Firs’ Sarn’t. Only then do Stein, or any of the rest of the C-for-Charl men for that matter, recognize that this Witt is their Wi the same that Stein and Welsh combined to transfer out of company. All of them are astonished, as Witt has obviousl meant for them to be.

By God! Hello, Witt! What’re you doing here? True to his promise of a few days before, Witt passes his narrow eyes across his friend as if Fife did not exist. T come to rest on Welsh again. Welsh seems to peer into him
You must be out of your mind. You must be crazy.

Hi, Witt. You in the medics now? You better get down. Stein, who has felt guilty about shipping Witt out when h knew how badly Witt wanted to stay, even though he still feels he did what was best for his company, says nothing.  63. Witt ignores Welsh's cautioning and remains standing stra up.
Naw, Firs’ Sarn’t, I'm still in Cannon Comp’ny. Where you put me. Only we ain’t got no cannons. who we goin’ after over there, Firs’ Sarn’t?
Jacques.

Old Jockey? Shit, that's too bad. His three companions have already gone on and are now run downhill toward the wounded man. Witt turns to follow the but then he turns back and speaks directly to Stein.
Please, sir, can I come back to the company? After we get Jockey back to Battalion? I can slip away easy. They'11 give Hoke another man. Can I, sir?
Well, I -- Of course, you'll have to get permission.

Sure. And my rifle. Thank you, sir. He exchanges a look with Welsh, who turns to Stein as tho to protest this decision. Then, continuing to ignore Fife turns and follows after his companions. Stein stares afte him. For a man to want to come back into a forward rifle company in the midst of an attack is simply incomprehensi In a way, though, it is very romantic -- like something o of Kipling. Fife lies flat and shuts his eyes. Even though he knows t Witt's gesture of ignoring him has to do with their argum of a few days back, he cannot help taking it as contempt disgust for his present cowardice -- as if Witt with one glance had looked inside his mind. when he reopens his ey he finds himself looking into the pleading white face of little Bead a few feet away.  64.

First chance I hadda be free of that goddamn Storm and all them cooks cooking up a bunch of shit for people to gorge their guts on. First chance I had to talk to the Comp'ny C'mander, personally, like this. Fife looks at him in astonishment. For one thing, it is a long time since anyone heard Charlie Dale string this man sentences together. He really does seem to be enjoying it especially watching Storm all flattened out beside Sgt. Welsh.
People are starting to rekinize me. (glancing at Storm) Hour ago that dumb fuck was giving me orders.

We know the Japs have vacated the ridge on the left. Dale, you go to 3rd Platoon, tell them to move up and occupy it. Report to Lieutenant Gore if you can find him. Tell him I don't want to lose any more men than he has to. Get back as soon as you can.
Aye, aye, sir.
I want both you and Doll to stay with me. I'll have further work for both of you. You've both been invaluable.
Yes, sir. Dale snaps out a tiny little salute and takes off, runnin bent over along the low area behind the fold.

The ridge on the right is going to be the trouble spot. The main strongpoint is there. Doll, you go back and tell 1st Platoon I want them to fire cover. Go!  65. Doll moves off reluctantly. He did not intend, when he fi came back, to set himself up as a troubleshooting messeng to dangerous areas for Bugger Stein.

2nd Platoon will make the attack. Sgt. Keck, as 2nd Platoon leader, you're to lead it. (guiltily) You'll take three squads and attack up the ridge. It won't be easy. Crawl up the slope as far as you can get, until they discover you. Then attack. The rest of us will move forward to support you. We're going after them, men. Keck listens, astonished. It will be a frontal attack uphill, under heavy fire. Meanwhile, Doll passes up through 2nd Platoon, at the thi swell. The men, cheeks pressed to the earth, stare at him with indifferent, sullen curiosity. He is aware that his are narrowed, his nostrils flared, his jaw set. He makes handsome picture of a soldier for the 2nd Platoon men who watch him. Then he is up and running. Some bullets kick u dirt to right and left. He zigs and zags. Finally, just a of him, he sees a hand and arm shoot up into the air, the hand describing the old circular hand-and-arm signal for "Gather here." Doll pulls up to find Queen lying placidly his side and grinning up at him ruefully, his rifle hugge against his chest.
Come right in.

Stein begins to move forward. Patches of flesh on his fac twitch uncontrollably. From behind the third swell he wil mount the attack and observe it too. He wonders if the me can tell his nerves are wearing thin. In the first place can never be sure that what he is doing is right, might n be done better and with less cost in some other way. Dang flickers and blinks in the air like a faulty neon tube. Whenever he stands up he might be struck by a bullet Whenever he moves a few feet he might be moving under a descending mortar shell. He is turning these things over in his mind when Fife hol the phone up to his ear. He is dumbfounded to hear the Colonel shouting at him that he is too far to the right.  66. He is not even given an opportunity to explain his propos attack.
I don't understand. What do you mean -- too far to the right? They've evacuated the left-hand grassy ridge. My 3rd Platoon's moving up to occupy it. Over.

God damn it, Stein! I'm telling you your left flank's exposed. Do' you know what it is to expose your flank? Did you ever read ina tactics manual about exposing your left flank? Damn it, you've got to move down there! You're not moving! Over.
God damn it, Colonel, right now, as you call, we're moving out to attack the right-hand grassy ridge. Over. God damn it.

Stein, you're too far right already! You're sideslipping to the right alla time. I've decided to commit the reserve company on your left -- with orders to attack! Orders to attack, Stein, you hear? Over.
Do you want me to go ahead with my attack? Over.

What else? What else, Stein? You're not supposed to be down there ona goddamned asshole vacation. Get cracking! Out. Stein looks over the terrain that lies ahead of them. He points its geography out to Band, Welsh and Keck
The first problem will be getting the men from here across that bareass field to the foot of the ridge. It'll be safer there. (MORE)

We'll be rSgiHIN(raya'ihst them, too close to hit us with their MGs and mortars. There's your ridge, Keck. You see? Suddenly Dale appears, running bent over at the waist in peculiar fashion everybody instinctively adopts. Rifle an FIRE hit the ground all around him, but nothing touches h and he arrives among them a hero. Everyone within reach s him on the back as he makes his way to Stein to give his report.

They’re okay. 3rd Platoon's occupied the ridge on the left. Stein sees a lone figure hurry toward him. It is Witt, wi his rifle and some extra bandoliers. At the same time, Pf Doll returns from his hazardous mission to 1st Platoon. Everything is building toward the moment of truth.
Found Queen. They're ready.
Dale, if you want to go out with these others when they make the attack, I'll make you an acting sergeant right now and put you in command of the extra squad. Do you want to do that?
Sure. Sure, sir. If you think I'm capable, sir. If you think I can do it.
Okay. I make you an acting sergeant. You'll go with the others. Under the command of Keck here.
Aye, sir. But don't you have to say hereby?
What?
I said: don't you have to say hereby? You know, to make it official.  68. In some slow-stirring, labyrinthine depth of his animal's mind Dale seems to be suspicious of Stein's honesty.

No. I don't have to say anything but what I've said. You're an acting sergeant. Dale turns to Doll and grins. While Doll gathers his brea and stricken sense of justice, Witt asks permission to jo the attack force. He seems to enjoy Welsh's look of exasperation.
Can I go, sir? I'm ready.

Can I go too, sir? Stein, unable to hide his stunned disbelief, nods his agreement. It gives him a terrible feeling of moral culpability to choose which men to send in. Some of them surely die, and he does not want to decide which ones. Le Luck choose, or whatever agency runs the lives of men.

All right, yes. Thank you, Doll. Doll crawls away biting the inside of his lip so hard tha brings tears to his eyes. Fife watches him bang his head violently against a rock, his whole body writhing like a snake's. Why does he do things like this to himself? Why can't he keep his mouth shut?
All right, Keck. When they're all there, space them out. Advance by rushes. You might as well go. we're counting on you.

Listen, Cap’n. There's somethin’ I wanted to tell you. That guy Bell is a good man. Pretty steady. He helped me get going and get the platoon out of that hole we were in after that charge. I just wanted to tell you.
Okay, I'll remember. Take care of yourself, Keck. I need you.  69.
I'll take care of myself as good as anybody can around here.

Give them hell, Sergeant! Give them hell! The two attacking squads soon separate themselves from th other half of the platoon. Most of them, in their bodily attitudes and in their faces, resemble sheep about to be to the slaughter pens in Chicago. They wait. Keck has onl crawl to them.

Okay, you guys. This is it. We're goin’ down in groups of four. No point in goin’ by rushes, only make a better target stopped. Run all the way. We ain't got any choice. We're picked, so we got to go. I’1l take the first bunch myself. I want Charlie Dale with me. Dale? You can organize them guys that's down there. Let's move out. He starts to crawl to the jump-off point just beyond the of officers and CP men, and it is here that the first cas overt cowardice occurs in C-for-Charlie. A big, beautiful muscled man named SICO, an Italian draftee from Philly, suddenly sits down in his tracks and begins to hold his stomach and groan.
Get up, God damn you, Sico. Or Ill kick you so hard in that stomach you'll really be sick.
I can't, Sergeant. I would if I could. You know I would. I'm sick.
Sick, my foot.
Hold it', Keck. What is it, Sico?

I don't know, Sergeant. It's my stomach. Pains. Cramps. I can't straighten up. I'm sick.  70. As if to prove it he suddenly vomits. He does not even tr bend over and the vomit burps up out of him and runs down over his fatigue shirt onto his hands which hold his bell He looks at Welsh hopefully out of the dark, tortured hol of his eyes, but appears ready to do it again if necessar
Leave him. (to Sico) Come on. The medics will take care of you, Sico.
Thank you, Sergeant. Keck seems to want to protest. Witt studies the scene. Welsh's indulgence is curious to him.

Don't argue with me. Sico continues to sit and watch the others pass. He groan audibly from time to time and now and then he gags, but apparently does not feel it necessary to vomit more. His looks haunted and his eyes tormented. Keck's men begin to run the gauntlet. Each squad sergeant first Milly Becker, then McCron -- supervises the jump-of his men in groups of four. All of them make it down safel except two. Of these, one, a Mississippi farmer named Cat is killed outright. The other, Pvt Alfredo Tella, hit running, falls, bounces hard and moans like a boy who has taken a spill from his bicycle. Unfortunately, the Japanese heavy mortars, still firmly seated on the heights of Hill 210, have seen the forward movement of American troops, too. Shells begin EXPLODING their fountains of terror, dirt and fragments as the Japa gunners finger the area. EXT. GRASSY SLOPE (KECK’S ATTACK) - DAY Keck spreads his men out in a line and then gives the ord to crawl. The grass is about chest-high here and has a matted, tangled underhayer of old stems. It chokes them w dust, ties up their arms and feet, makes it impossible to see. They crawl for what seems an eternity, expecting the Japanese to open up at any moment. It requires tremendous exertion. Most of them have long since used up all of the water. Halfway up the slope Keck orders them to stop.  71. For a moment he lies gathering his will power and thinks about their faces. Then, taking a deep breath he stands u straight in the grass.

Up! Up! Go! They rise in a line and begin to scamper uphill, FIRING a they go. Almost immediately the MGs begin to HAMMER, and once men begin to fall. The fury of the Japanese fire str them like a wind-tormented hailstorm. The Japanese have b smart and have waited, conserving their fire till they ha targets. Four men of McCron’s squad go down at once. On t right, a young draftee named Wynn is shot in the throat a screams, "Oh, my God!" in a voice of terror and disbelief a geyser of blood spurts from his neck. Next to him, anot soldier, is caught in the face, perhaps from the same bur He goes down without a sound, looking as if he's been hit the face with a tomato. All this is apparently too much f McCron, who has clucked over and mothered this squad for months, and he simply drops his rifle and sits down cryin Dale, on the left, sees the first emplacement, the first one any of them has ever actually seen. It is a one-gun j a simple hole dug in the ground and covered over with sti and kunai grass. From the dark opening he can see the muz SPITTING FIRE at him. So far Dale has not fired a shot. w is the point, when there are no targets? But now, seeing emplacement, he carefully releases his safety and FIRES a long burst with his Thompson gun, straight into the hole twenty yards away. Before he can release the trigger the jams solidly. But his burst is enough to stop the machine gun, at least momentarily, and Dale runs toward it pullin grenade from his shirt. From ten yards away he throws the grenade like a baseball, wrenching hell out of his should The grenade disappears through the hole, then BLOWS UP, scattering sticks and grass and three rag dolls and upend the machine gun. Dale turns back to his squad, licking hi lips and grinning with beady pride. MGs still hammer at them from seemingly every quarter of globe. Men are still going down. They still have not loca any main strongpoints. Directly in front of them thirty y away, there is a winding gully and four-foot cut which extends clear across their front. Instinctively everyone begins to run for that. They dive behind its protection pell-mell, sobbing with exhaustion. exertion and the heat have been too much. Several men vom One man gurgles once senselessly, then -- his eyes rollin back in his head -- faints from heat prostration. They li against the ledge in the midday sun and smell the hot, su smelling dust. Insects HUM around them. The fire has stop  72.
Well, what’re we gonna do now?
We're gonna stay right here. Maybe they'll get some reinforcements up to us.
Ha! To do what?
To capture these goddamn fucking positions around here! what you think?
You mean you really want to go on with it?

I don't know. No. Not no uphill charge. But they get us some reinforcements, we can scout around and maybe locate where all these goddamn fucking MGs are. Anyway, it's better than going back down through that. You want to go back down? Nobody answers this, and Keck does not feel it necessary elaborate. Witt studies the ants crawling on the ground.
McCron’s gone. Bell, I'm appointing you acting sergeant in his place.
What if the Japs come down here in force and throw us off of here?
I don't think they will. But we better have a sentry. Doll.
Somethin’s comin’!

They’re comin’! Somebody’s comin’! AS one man the line behind the cut sweeps up and forward, rifles ready.  73. Forty yards away seven pot-headed, bandy-legged, starved- looking Japanese men are running down-at them across an ungrassed area carrying hand grenades in their right hand and bayoneted rifles in their left. The massed rifle FIRE from the ledge disposes of them quickly. Only one of them able even to throw; and his grenade, a dud, lands short. the fire ceases, only two bodies continue to move. Aiming deliberately in the sudden quiet, Witt the Kentuckian put killing round into each one of them.
You never can tell about them boys. Even when they’re hit.
Why’d they do it? If they wanted to throw us out of here, why didn't they come in force? Why just seven? It don't figure.

Maybe they were doing it on their own. Without orders. They await a second, larger attack, but only four more Japanese appear. Witt, who is the best marksman in the regiment, quickly SHOOTS three down. Doll and Dale watch awe. Keck reaches in his hip pocket to pull out a grenade and-in the excitement he gets it by the pin. He and Bell exchange a look of dizzying, near-fainting terror, then h leaps back from the line and sits back against a little d hammock, to protect the others. The grenade goes off with sickening THUD. They see there is nothing they can do for him. His entire right buttock and much of his lower back been blown away.
What a fucking recruit trick to pull.
He jumped away -- so we wouldn't get hit. Bell and Doll sit with him while the others go back to th line. They wipe the mud off his face and try to reassure
We'll take care of you, Keck. I swear to God we will! Just take it easy.  74.
You guys write my old lady, will you? Don't forget. I want her to know I died like a man.

Sure, sure. But nobody's gonna haf to write your old lady. You'll come out of this. We got stretcher- bearers with us, remember? Battalion Aid Station's movin' up all the time. They'll have you back to the docs in no time.
Bullshit. Don't bullshit me. I'm cold.
There, there. Just take it easy.
You guys don't forget to write my old lady I died like a man. He sighs, first sign of the approaching breathlessness of massive hemorrhage.

I grabbed it by the pin. This fuckin’ mud on my face! Bell wets his handkerchief and cleans Keck's face with it This seems to make him feel better. Becker turns from the to signal the company to send reinforcements.
Just don't forget to write my old lady I died like a man.
Just take it easy. Don't talk like that. You'll make it out of this.
Horseshit. I'm bleedin’ to death. Ain't I? He looks at Witt, who does not answer but watches him wit sympathy.  75.
See? Maybe it's just as good. I'm all messed upon the crock. What if I couldn't fuck no more? Just don't forget to write my old lady I died manly.

Sure, sure. I'll write her. Just take it easy. Witt comes up. Doll and Bell drift away. Witt is calm and cheerful in the presence of death; he does not look away. feels a bond with the dying man. The others are solemn, embarrassed.
Aid Station’s never gonna get up here. The medics either.

You're gonna be all right. Even if you die. You didn't let your brother down... Those flies bothering you? He whisks the flies away from Keck's face and waits. His express a deep understanding and tenderness.
We'll remember what you done. We won't forget it. It won't be wasted. Keck looks at him uncomprehendingly. The others return. T breathlessness has hit him; they know it won't be long.
I'm cold. Freezin’! When he stops breathing, the men stand up.
You going to write his wife?
Fuck no! I don't know his old lady. That's the Company Commander's job not mine. You out of your mind? I ain't no good at writin’ letters.
You told him you would.  76.
I say anything when they're like that.
Somebody ought to do it.
Then you write her.
I didn't tell him I would.

(to Doll) You make me sick. Squaring his shoulders, he stares at Doll, ready to fight then and there, in the midst of combat. Doll does not wan fight. witt turns away in disgust. Charlie Dale comes ove
All over?
Yeah.

head_text.subj: THIRD FOLD TO CUT, (WITH BINOCULAR MATTE)

text: Stein, through his binoculars, sees the men clustered aro the figure on the ground, two hundred yards away. Keck! T he sees that Sgt. Becker is looking at him -or anyway tow him -- and making the Old Army hand-and-arm signal for "Converge on me." He wants reinforcements. Exertion, nerv exhaustion and fear are wearing Stein down.

He wants help... That whole ridge is a giant honeycomb of MG emplacements. A regular fortress. The attack's bogged down. They aren't enough men. It'd take a full company . (to Band) Twelve men down! I counted every one of them. My men!... Now he wants us to send more after them. Suddenly Stein hears from near the foot of the ridge the first thin, piping YELLS. They sound insane.  77. What they lack in volume, they more than make up in their penetrating qualities. They come in a series, each lastin five full seconds. Then there is silence.
What's that?

My God! Band looks back at him with squinted, dilated eyes. From high grass out beyond them, high and shrill, the series o yells comes again. They are not screams. Stein is able to pick him out easily with the glasses, which brings him up very close, too close for comfort. Pvt Tella -- he has fa at the bottom of the slope. Now he is trying to crawl bac He has been hit squarely in the groin with a burst of hea MG fire which has torn his whole belly open. Lying on his back, his head uphill, both hands pressed to his belly to hold his intestines in, he is inching his way toward them
Tella. Medic!

What are we gonna do? From below the insane series of YELLS comes again, identi unchanging. Stein and Band aren't the only ones to hear t The entire remainder of the 2nd Platoon lying along the c of the swell have heard him. So has the Medic who is now running bent over along the slope to Stein. Fife pricks h ears. The mortar shells are still falling every minute or two. Sometimes you can hear their fluttery SHU-ING sound two seconds before they hit; and Fife is completely terrorized by them.
There's nothing anybody can do that’ll help him. He'll be dead before they can ever get him back to a surgeon. He's got dirt all over his bowels. Even sulfa won't fix that. In these jungles?
How long?
Two hours? Four, maybe? Maybe only one. Maybe less.  The Medic 78.
God damn it, man! We can't any of us stand it that long! Not counting him! And I can't ask you to go down there.
studies the terrain. He blinks several times.
Maybe it's worth a try.
You said yourself nobody could do anything to help him.
At least I could get a syrette of morphine into him.
Would one be enough? I mean, you know, would it keep him quiet?
Not for long. But I could give him two. I could leave him three or four for himself.
Maybe he wouldn't take them. He's delirious. Couldn't you just, sort of, give them all to him at once?
That would kill him, sir. I couldn't do that, I really couldn't.
Okay -- well, you want to try it? From below the set, unchanging series of YELLS rises up t them, precise, inflexible, a little quavery this time.
I hope he doesn't begin to cry. God damn it! My company won't have any fighting spirit left at all if we don't do something about him!  79.
I'll go, sir. After all, it's my job. After all, it's worth a try, isn't it, sir? To stop the yells.
God, I don't know.
I'm volunteering. I've been down there before. They won't hit me, sir.
You were on the left. It's not as bad there.
I'm volunteering. Agonized, Stein waits several seconds before he speaks.
When do you want to go?
Any time. Right now.
No, wait. At least I can give you some covering fire.

I'd rather go now, sir. And get it over with. They have been lying side by side, their helmets almost touching as they talk, and now Stein turns to look at the boy. He cannot help wondering whether he has talked this into volunteering.

Okay. Go ahead. The Medic nods, looking straight ahead this time, then springs up into a crouch, and is gone over the crest of t swell. It is all over almost before it gets started. Running lik some fleeting forest animal, his medic's web equipment flopping, he reaches the damaged Tella, swings round to f him up the hill, then drops to his knees, his hands alrea groping at the pouch which holds his syrettes.  80. Before he can get the cap off the needle, one single MG O uP from the ridge stitching across the area. Stein and th remnants of 2nd Platoon watch him jerk straight up, eyes mouth wide, face slack, not so much with disbelief or men shock as with sheer simple physiological surprise. Stein waits. Seconds ago he was alive and Stein was talki to him; now he is dead. Just like that. But Stein's atten is pulled away before he can think more, pulled away by t things. One is Tella, who now begins to scream in a high babbling falsetto of hysteria totally different from his former yells. Obviously he has been hit again, and while bloodstained hand tries to hold in his intestines, the ot gropes at the new wound in his chest.

Cly, Yank, cly! Yerl, Yank, yerl! The next thing that catches Stein's attention is a figure emerging from the grass fifty yards ahead and plodding steadily toward them. Stein sees that it is his Sgt. McCr that he is wringing his hands and weeping. On his face tw great white streaks of clean skin run from eye to chin, accentuating the eyes, as if he were wearing the haunting makeup of a tragic actor in some Greek drama. And on he comes, while behind him Japanese MGs and small OPEN UP all across the ridge, making dirt puffs all aroun him. Nothing touches him. At last he sits down beside his Captain.
Dead. All dead, Cap’n. Every one. I'm the only one. All twelve. Young men. I looked after them. Taught them everything I knew. It didn't mean a thing. Dead. What more can you do?
They can't all be dead, McCron.
(in a rage) I tried to help them! All gone! They 're all gone! Wynn! Gordon! Darl! Gwenne! Vincente! Mack!
Medic! Take him back. Stay with him. When you get back there, tell them we need another medic now. At least one.  81.
Yes, sir. Come on, Mac. That's it Come on, boy. It'll be all right. It'll be all right.

They're all dead. How can it be all right? Why? Why? Why? He allows himself to be led off by the arm. Stein sighs a turns his attention back to Tella. The Italian is still screaming his piercing wailing scream and does not seem t show any indication that he is ever going to run down. If keeps on, it is going to unnerve them all. Stein does not know what to do. He cannot send another man out there. A unbelieving, outraged fury seizes him. And just then a la green object of nature on his right rises up and bounds o the crest of the swell, growling obscenities. Before Stei can even yell the one word, "Welsh!", the First Sergeant careering across the field at full gallop toward the ridg

Welsh sees everything before him with a furious clarity: rocky, thin-grassed field running off to the foot of the ridge, mortar-and bullet-pocked, the hot bright sunshine deep cerulean sky, the incredibly white clouds above the towering high-up horseshoe of Hill 210, the yellow sereni of the ridge before him.

Fuck you! Fuck you! He charges on happily, zigzagging professionally . But wh he skids to a stop on his belly beside the mutilated Ital boy, he realizes he has made no plans about what to do wh he arrives here.
How goes it, kid? Tella rolls his eyes around like a maddened horse until h can see who it is. He does not stop his screaming.

You got to be quiet. I came to help you. Tella! Finally the scream stops of itself, from lack of breath, Tella breathes, causing more blood to run from the hole i his chest. When he speaks, it is only a few decibels lowe than the scream.  82.
Fuck you! I'm dying! I'm dying, Sarge! Look at me! Get away from me! I'm dying!
Okay, but goddamn it, do it with less noise.
How you going to help me?
Take you back.
You can't take me back! You want to help me, shoot me!
(yelling in the noise) You're off your rocker. You know I can't do that.
Sure you can! You got your rifle there! Point it at me! You want to help me, shoot me and get it over with! I can't stand it! I'm scared!
Does it hurt much?
Sure it hurts, you dumb son of a bitch! You can’t take me back

We'll see. You stick with old Welsh. Trust old Welsh. Did I ever give you a bum steer? He is aware now -- he knows -- that he won't be able to s much longer. Already he is flinching and jerking uncontrollably under the fire. Crouching, he runs around Tella's head and gets him under the armpits and heaves.
Aaa-eeeee! You're killing me! You're pulling me apart! Put me down, goddamn you! Put me down! Welsh drops him quickly, by simple reflex. Too quickly.  83.
You son of a bitch! You son of a bitch! Leave me alone! Leave me alone! Don't touch me! Why are you touching me?
(yelling) Stop that yelling. It ain't dignified. All right, we'll do it this way, then. Slipping one arm under the Italian's knees and the other under his shoulders, he lifts.

Aaa-eeeee! Put me down! Put me down! You're breaking me in two! Put me down! You'll kill me! You son of a bitch! You fucker! You bastard! I told you to leave me alone! I never ast you to come down here! Go away! Leave me alone! You shiteater! Stay away from me! Turning his head away and closing his eyes, he begins his desperate, wailing, piercing scream again. Five yards abo them on the slope a line of machine gun BULLETS slowly stitches itself across from left to right. With sudden, desperate inspiration, Welsh leaps across the prostrate T and begins rummaging in the dead Medic's belt pouches.
Here! Tella! Take these! Tella! Tella stops screaming and opens his eyes. Welsh tosses hi two morphine syrettes he has found and begins to attack another pouch.

More! More! Gimme more! More! Welsh tosses him a double handful he has found in the oth pouch, and then turns to run. But something stops him. Crouched like a sprinter at the gun, he turns his head an looks at Tella one more time. Tella, already unscrewing t cap from one of the syrettes, is looking at him feelingly his eyes wide and white.
Goodbye! Goodbye, Welsh!  84.

Goodbye, kid. It is all he can think of to say. For that matter, it is he has time to say, because he is already off and running Bullets WHIR by his head. He runs and runs and then he fa headlong over the little crest and just lies there, half- from exhaustion.
Sergeant, I saw the whole thing through the glasses. I want you to know I'm mentioning you in Orders tomorrow. I'm recommending you for the Silver Star. I can only say --

Captain, if you say one word to thank me, I will punch you square in the nose. Right here. If you ever so much as mention me in your fucking orders, I will resign my rating two minutes after, and leave you to run this pore, busted-up outfit by yourself. If I go to jail. So fucking help me. He shuts his eyes and rolls over away from Bugger, who sa nothing.

Property! Property! Witt has perceived Welsh's selfless aid to the dying man. They glance at one another. Stein slowly crawls back to F and the soundpower phone. His arm is trembling as he take the receiver. How long can he go on? How much longer can watch his men being killed in agony like this? His CP for and the remnants of 2nd and 3rd Platoons watch him with w eyes, as though looking to him and hoping he can in some get them out of this mess, so that they might go on livin

Why aren't you following up your attack and exploiting it? What's the matter with you, Stein? Those men should be reinforced immediately. What are they doing? I can see them through my glasses. They're just lying behind that ledge. They should be up and out cleaning out those machine guns. Over.

I don't think you understand what's going on down here, sir. We're taking a lot of fire. We've had heavy casualties. I was planning to reinforce them right away; something bad happened. We had a man -- gut shot out on the slope -- he caused quite a bit of upset. That's taken care of now. I’m planning to reinforce now. Over

Who was that man who ran out on the slope? Was that what he was doing? Admiral Barr saw him through the glasses; the Admiral couldn't tell for sure but thought he had gone out to help someone. Was that it? The Admiral wants to recommend that man for something. Over.

There were two men who went out, sir. One was our senior medic. He was killed. The other -- was one of the privates. I don't know which one yet. I'll find out. Over. (releasing the button) And fuck you. And the Admiral.
Fine. Fine, fine. Now, what about those reinforcements? Over.
I have two squads to 1st Platoon, I can send up... I lost Keck Colonel. One of my best men... Over.

What the hell do you mean, two squads! When I say reinforcements, I mean it. Throw every man you have in there, and do it now. Commit the reserve platoon and all. Everybody. 1st Platoon too. I see them lying on their fat asses down there doing nothing. Move them by the flank in to the ridge. Get a man to them right now with orders to attack.. (MORE )
Have the 2@@LP.lditdn( qoretssd the center. Go straight up the hill! Envelop them. Do I have to give you a lesson in infantry tactics while your men are getting their asses shot off, Stein? Over.

(swallowing his wrath) I don't think you fully understand what's going on down here, Colonel. I don't think my company alone can take that position. They're too well dug in. They have too much firepower. Colonel, there's a bunker up there, we can't see it it's chewing my men to pieces. I formally request, sir, to be given permission to make a patrol reconnaissance around to the right of Hill 210 through the jungle. A flanking move. It might save lives. I believe the entire position can be outflanked by a maneuver there in force.

No! I tell you, no! I want a double envelopment! I order you, Stein, to attack, attack now, with every man at your disposal! Now, attack Stein! That's a direct order! Over His heart suddenly up in his throat, Stein hears himself answer with a sort of numb disbelief.

Sir, I must tell you that I refuse to obey your order. I again request permission to make a patrol reconnaissance in force around to the right. The time, sir, is thirteen twenty-one hours twenty- five seconds. I have two witnesses here listening to what I've said. I request, sir, that you inform witnesses there. Over. The fact is that by now there are many more witnesses, at least half of 2nd Platoon is listening with its ears pric
Stein! Don't pull that guardhouse lawyer shit with me, Stein! (MORE)
I know you Cat .a TAdddenmred' dpwyer ! Now shut up and do like I tell you. I didn't hear what you just said! I repeat my order! Over!

Colonel, I refuse to take my men up there in a frontal attack It's suicide! I've lived with these men two-and-a-half years. I won't order them all to their deaths. That's final. Over. Someone is blubbering now not far away along the crest, a Stein tries to see who it is and can't. Tall is stupid, ambitious, desperate to succeed before his superiors and fearful the battalion will be pulled back off the line be he can. Otherwise he could never have given such an order Stein seems to read approval in his men's eyes. Tall's vo is sharp as a razor.

This is a very important decision you're making, Stein. If you feel that strongly, maybe you have reason. I'm coming down. I'm not rescinding my* order to you, but if I find there are extenuating circumstances when I get down there, I'll take that into account. I want you to hold on until I get there. If possible, get those men on the ridge out and moving. I'll be there in ten minutes. Out! Stein listens unbelieving, mentally stunned. Moving up, h arrives at the wounded man, who proves to be Pfc Bead fro Iowa, Fife's assistant clerk. Bead is dying.
I'm dying, Captain! I'm dying! Me! Me! I'm dying! I'm so scared! He closes his eyes for a moment and swallows. Fife comes with the telephone, wide-eyed.
I was just laying there. It hit me right in the side. Like somebody punched me. Didn't hurt much. Doesn't hurt much now. Oh, Captain!  88.
Just take it easy, son. Just take it easy.
Where's Fife?
He's right here, son. Right here. Fife!
I'm here.
I'm dying, Fife!
I know. Just take it easy. Just take it easy, Eddie.
Will you write my folks? (as Fife nods) Tell them it didn't hurt me much. Tell them the truth.
I'll tell them.

Hold my hand, Fife. I'm scared. For a moment, a second, Fife hesitates. Then, realizing w horror that Bead is slipping away, he grips his hand. Crawling closer, he slides his other arm under his should cradling him. He has begun to cry, more because he suddenly realizes th he is the only man in the whole company whom Bead can cal friend, than because Bead is dying. Ah, what a poor frien he's been!
I've got it.
Squeeze. Squeeze.
I'm squeezing.  89. He leans forward and presses Bead's hand against his chee Bead gives a little cry.
Oh, Fife! Oh, Captain! His eyes do not go shut but they cease to see. After a mo Fife puts him down and crawls away by himself, weeping in terror, weeping in fear, weeping in sadness, hating himse
Lie down somewhere for a little bit, son. I'll keep the phone for a few minutes myself. There won't be any calls coming in for a while.
Back at the cut, Becker's men are growing nervous. Where the reinforcements? Doll glances nervously at Witt.

We're just going to get killed if we stay here. They're not going to just let us set. Bell, take six men, go around to the right of the ledge, see what's up there. we'll stay here and cover you best we can. Bell sets off with his men. Everything works from the beginning. Finding the cut totally unguarded, they are ab to crawl into the midst of the Japanese position and drop grenades down into the rear doors of two covered, camoufl emplacements they spot down below them; two further emplacements, on the uphill side, are more difficult, but bypassing them and crawling up alongside they are able to pitch grenades into the apertures. Father up , Bell discovers the Japanese strongpoint beautifully dug in and with apertures in three directions does not see it all at first. When the lead man climbs ou he is RIDDLED fatally by three machine guns. Both Witt an Doll are in Bell's party, but neither of them happens to the lead man. This distinction is reserved for a man name Catch, Lemuel C. Catch, an old-time regular. He dies immediately and without a sound. They pull his body down retreat with it, while all hell breaks loose FIRING just above their heads, but not before Acting Sergeant Bell ge good look at the strongpoint so he can describe it.  90.

Wait here. Halting his men a few yards back from where Catch died, leaving his rifle and holding a grenade in one hand, Bell climbs up pokes up his head. The Japanese firing has stop now. All he can see is the unending grass, rising slowly along a hillock which sticks up out of the ridge. He wait wondering if he will die, then pulling the pin, heaves th grenade with all his strength and ducks down. The grenade falls and EXPLODES just in front of the hillock, and in t cyclone of MG FIRE which follows, Bell is able to count f guns in five spitting apertures which he could not see before. He notes it all carefully and when the firing cea he crawls back down to his men, obscurely satisfied.

There's five -- five guns. Whatever it was that made him do it, and he still doesn't know, it makes every man in his little group look at him admiringly . Dale, Doll, Witt, especially Witt. Motioning them on, he leads them back down until the company's main position at the third swell comes into view. To their surprise they have not seen or heard a single Japanese anywhere near the ledge.
Don't make sense. For them to leave this place unguarded.

The mortar ROUNDS continue to drop at random points along swell with strict regularity. It is amazing how few men t actually wound or kill. Fife hears the soft "SHU-U-U" of mortar shell for perhaps half a second. There is not even time to connect it with himself, before there is a huge sunburst roaring of an EXPLOSION almost on top of him. He has a vague impression of someone screaming but does n know it is himself. Fife's body comes to rest in the lap H.Q's man who happens to be sitting up.
Am I hit? Am I hit?
Y-yes, you are. In the head.
Bad? Is it bad?  91.
I c-can't tell. Y-you're bleeding from your head.
Am I? Fife looks at his hands and finds them completely covered with a glistening red. Gingerly he probes at his skull an finds nothing.
I-it's in the b-back. (fearfully) How do you f-feel?
I don't know. It don't hurt. Except when I touch it.
C-can you w-walk?

I-I don't know. Then, suddenly, Fife realizes that he is free. He does no have to stay here any more. He is released. He can simply up and walk away -- provided he is able -- with honor, without anyone being able to say he is a coward or court- martialing him.
I think I better go back. Don't you? Well -- Good luck, Train.

Th-thanks. Fife stands up. His knees are shaky, but the prospect of getting out of here gives him a strength he might not otherwise have. At first slowly, then more swiftly, he be to walk rearward. Just before he breasts the top of the h he meets Colonel Tall and a party of his aides.

Hold on, son. Don't let it get you down. You'll be back! Beyond the hill, he passes a barefoot Melanesian in a lavalava who is leading an American soldier with a bandag over his eyes back to the rear.  92.
Stein watches Bell's party through his glasses, astonishe They did it all on their own!
There's less fire coming from the hill, sir.
I've noticed that too.
They've knocked out some of those machine guns. In fact, they've cleaned out all the Japanese below the ledge.
Sir? I think the medics can go out pick up the wounded now.

Send ist Platoon forward. We'll follow them. Stein is just turning to lead the CP up toward the ledge, join Becker and Bell and to consolidate their newly won position, when he looks up to see Col. Tall walking leisu toward him, carrying beneath his arm the unadorned little bamboo baton that is his trademark and romantic whim. Bell's raid has cleaned out the Japanese below the ledge established a real line. It has utterly changed the situation, and it is one of those horrible ironies which to dog the steps of certain men named Stein-that just at moment Col. Tall should walk onto the field.
What are you doing lying down there where you can't see anything?

Observing, sir. I just sent 1st Platoon forward to the ridge. Tall nods. The rest of his party, which includes a young captain named GAFF, his battalion exec, has decided that might be just as well to be lying flat on the ground.  A mortar anybody, to where haunches. 93.
I saw them leaving as we were coming along. How many of them were hit this time?
None, sir.
None? Not one? round mushrooms, EXPLODING dirt without hurting somewhere along the rear, and Tall, coming forward Stein lies, permits himself to squat on his
That doesn't sound much like the situation you described to me over the soundpower.
It's not, sir. The situation's changed. In just the last five minutes.
To what do you attribute the change?

Sergeant Becker, sir. When I last looked, half of his men had disappeared. I think he sent them off to try and knock out some of the MGs. They seem to have succeeded. From somewhere far off a machine gun begins to RATTLE and long line of bullets strikes up dirt twenty-five yards be them. Tall does not change his position or alter his voic
Then you got my message to him.
No, sir. Becker sent the men off on his own. They went off on their own.
I see.  94. The long line of MG BULLETS comes sweeping back from Stei left, this time only fifteen yards away. Tall does not mo but merely squints his blue eyes off at the grassy ridge silence.
They've seen you, sir.
Stein, we're going over there, all of us, and we're taking everybody with us. Do you have any more formal complaints or demurrers?
No, sir. Not now.
Now we'll do things my way. We'll take everybody over to the ledge. We may take that ridge before nightfall.

I think that ridge is quite a way from being reduced, sir. Tall ignores this remark and stands up to his full height The conference is over. Tall gives the ridge one contempt amused look and starts walking out toward it, still talki to Stein. Slowly, very slowly, Stein stands up to his ful height also, then follows Tall out into the field where t minutes before they would have met a certain death. Around them, as if sensing something or other is in the w the men begin to stir. Whatever else Stein can find to sa about him, he nevertheless has to admit that with Tall's arrival on the battlefield a change for the better has co over everything and everybody. Tall has brought with him quality that has not been here before, and it shows in th faces of the men. Standing up in front of the prone H.Q. Platoon, his little baton in his right hand, tapping it lightly against his shoulder as he frowns in concentratio he orders them forward and shows them how he wants them t advance. He does not exhort them. His attitude says quite plainly that they deserve better than that. Gathering hea the men rush forward in groups.  95.
Becker and Bell, Witt, Dale and Doll wait at the ledge. A the others scramble up to join them, there are a few weak cheers.

That strongpoint is the key to the ridge. Se -- uh -- Sergeant Bell here is quite right. From their knob there our little brown brothers can cover the whole of the ground in front of our position for a thousand yards. Why they've left it unguarded I have no idea. We must exploit it before they see their error. I know everyone's pretty exhausted and that we've had our troubles getting water up here, but if we can reduce that big bunker, I see no reason why we can't take the whole ridge before nightfall. I'm asking for volunteers to go back up there and knock it out. Stein, hearing for the first time this news about a furth attack, is so horrified he can hardly believe his ears. Surely Tall must know how worn out they all are.

Sir, I'll be glad to go back again and lead the way for a party. Immediately off to Bell's right another voice pipes up. H shouldered, crack-faced Acting Sergeant Dale is making hi bid for future fame, future sinecures, future security fr army kitchens.

I'll go, Colonel, sir! what about you, Doll? Doll nods his agreement, without looking at Dale, and Pri Witt comes forward at the same time. Both sit down, much closer to Bell than to Dale, who still squats by himself. Bell winks at Witt, who grins and winks back. The rather elderly, Calvinistic-looking 2nd lieutenant fr 3rd Platoon presents himself. His name is GORE. Then Tall own exec, young Captain Gaff, puts in his two cents and offers his services.  96.
